abstract.p: Lawrence Howe letter defends bookstore practice of shelving books according to their topics (May 8 Op-Ed)

block.p: For an author, Ward Connerly displays a remarkable lack of understanding about books and marketing (''Where 'Separate but Equal' Still Rules,'' Op-Ed, May 8). Bookstores and libraries shelve books according to their topic, not their author's race.

For an author, Ward Connerly displays a remarkable lack of understanding about books and marketing (''Where 'Separate but Equal' Still Rules,'' Op-Ed, May 8). Bookstores and libraries shelve books according to their topic, not their author's race.

These practices do not limit opportunities for writers or readers of any race. It may come as a surprise to Mr. Connerly to learn that I, a white reader, often peruse books shelved in the ''African-American interest'' section, and I've even bought some.

Beyond that, Mr. Connerly exhibits political ignorance by equating bookstore shelving practices with the atrocities of racial profiling and forced segregation. Such an unfortunate analogy is an insult to the victims of constitutional crimes.
The writer is an associate professor of English at Roosevelt University.
